Players have two options a turn, they may either launch as many as up to 5 game pieces from their ship's cannon doors towards the enemy. Or, move all their pieces on the net forward one space, either forward or diagonally up/down. Player pieces that land on the opponent's pieces remove the enemy pieces from the game.

If a player's pieces reach the other ship, they will destroy the opponent's cannon door and any pieces behind it. The player's piece is also returned to the player's ship to again enter the net.

The optimal game end is when one player removes all the other player's pieces from the board.

An added complication is that pieces moving up or down off the net return on the opposite top or bottom, depending on movement.

name: Wie, Wat, Waar?
description:
Family game, slightly related to "Guess Who".
Several themes are represented and expressed in the 4 double-sided game cards.
You have to choose from a picture that your opponent then has to guess. Questions which can be answered only by yes or no.
If you guess the right image you win.
The four themes: transport, world-children, flags and animals.

Extra possibility is the use of two images, to guess on.

name: Landlocked: Hither and Yon
description:
Travel as you please, from hither to yon. Just don’t become Landlocked!

The goal is to construct a correct path through 12 locations. Moving orthogonally, move your pawn from the upper left to the null tile of your outbound suit. You may move your pawn through a higher-valued outbound tile en route to the current value your pawn is heading towards. However you may not pass through any tile on your inbound suit. Once this is done, you must mark each tile you passed through After all the tiles you passed through are marked, move on to the ace tile of your outbound suit, marking each tile you passed through as before. Continue on in this manner and in order to tiles Ace-5 of the outbound suit to 5-Null of the inbound suit. When you are working on your inbound suit, you may pass through any and all tiles on your outbound suit. However you may not pass through an inbound tile that has a value lower than the current value your pawn is moving towards.

name: What Everyone Should Know About GREAT INVENTIONS
description:
From the publisher:
This game makes the cogwheels of your brain turn. Do you know who invented the bicycle, and how Blu-ray differs from DVD? If you don’t, find out with What everyone should know about the greatest inventions!
On each turn players take one card and try to answer to the question on there! When getting the answer right you get 10 of the money the game uses! Then you have another change to go! Get it right again, you get 20, then 50, then 100 and then you have to give away your turn!
You win the game when collecting amount of money agreed with other players at the beginning of the game! For example you win, when you get 250 that money!

name: Vild med dyr
description:
Vild med dyr ('Crazy about animals') is a Danish trivia gamed about animals for 2-4 player or teams. The payers/teams start at home in each their corner of the game board and have to correctly answer a question (of a self-selected category) in order to get out of the home and onto the game path. On turn each player (out of home) throws a die to move their animal-shaped marker around the board and has to answer questions in one of the five categories depending on the color of the board tile landed upon. A players may change direction on the board after each turn.

The four main categories are:
Lilac: Soft and close (domestic animals) - in Danish: 'Blød & Nær (husdyr og landburgsdyr)'
Blue: Beaks and fins (birds, fishes, and sea mammals) - in Danish: 'Næb & Finner (fugle, fisk og havpattedyr)'
Light brown: Vild and warm (wild life mammals) - in Danish: 'Vild & Varm (vildtlevende pattedyr)'
Green: Creeping and crawling (insects, frogs, amphibians and reptiles) - in Danish: 'Kryb & Kravl (insekter, føer, padder og krybdyr)'

The fifth additional joker category is:
White: Fun and crazy (problems and challenges) - in Danish: 'Fis & Ballade (opgaver og udfordringer)'

The players collect paws (plastic chips with a paw imprint) in the four main colors by correctly answering questions of the respective colors. The white category cover a variety of challenges to be fulfilled in a certain time (such as naming a certain number of animals starting with a particular letter, or drawing or acting a particular animal) or simply an order to transfer a certain number of paws to or from another player or the stock.

If a player land on a tile occupied by another player, the other players is returned to home and have to start out again (keeping the paws collected so far).

The winner is the player or team who first collect three paws of each color and get back home.

Content:
Game board
Rules
4 animal-shaped game pieces
48 paws - 12 in each main color
1 die
2 boxes with a total of 300 cards with 1500 questions and challenges
4 pads of drawing paper
4 pencils
1 30-seconds hourglass

name: Black Stories Junior: Yellow Stories
description:
A game similar to Black Stories. One player reads the riddle in front of the card. The other players try to guess what's happened. The answer on the back of the card is read by the storyteller. The storyteller can only answer yes/no.
The Yellow Stoires are about the prairies, indians, cowboys and medicine men.

name: Cannes: Stars, Scripts and Screens – Mini Expansion
description:
The mini expansion of "Cannes: Stars, Scrips & Screens" introduces two additional rules for the original game:


pirate ship: allowing to show a pre-release version of a movie.
storing of tiles: allowing to store tiles in the week schedule.


The mini expansion was a give-away at the fair in Essen (probably in 2003) and contains a sheet of English rules and a wooden ship tile (both delivered in a zip-lock plastic bag).
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Voyage en France
description:
Voyage en France is the same game as Journey through Europe, Deutschlandreise or Weltreise.

Each player receives some destination cards with places in France. The players have to move along the board by throwing a die. The first player who has visited all of his/her destination cards and arrives back in the starting place wins the game.
mechanics: Pick-up and Deliver, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Point Final
description:
Most of the cards in this card game are letter cards, with which a word is formed; the rest are special action cards. Each player has six cards at the start of the game; the goal is to get rid of one's cards first.
The first player plays a card on the table; this card will be the first letter of a word that s/he thinks about (but doesn't say out loud). The next player adds a second letter to the word, etc. There are many jokers, so there are also many possibilities for what a word might be. When a player doubts that the last player can still think of a word starting with the letters on the table, s/he can call the bluff. If the previous players cannot produce a word, the bluffing player must pick up the cards from the table, if s/he can, the accusing player picks them up. Instead of playing a card, a player can also choose to draw a new card from the stack, but still takes responsibility for the word on the table (i.e., if called, must produce a word with these letters).
By placing a facedown card on the table, any player (out of turn order), can announce that a word is complete. The letters are then discarded and a new word is started.

There are various special cards with which players can be forced to say a word with the current letters, cards can be passed to other players, etc.

When a player plays his or her last card, the other players count the points printed on their remaining cards. These are their negative scores.
publishers: Percot Rondeau Éditions, Pink Monkey Games

name: Monopoly: AC/DC Collector's Edition
description:
Publisher Blurb:

The AC/DC Collector’s Edition of Monopoly is the first and only game that combines the risk taking, deal making Monopoly game play with one of the most legendary and enduring rock ‘n roll bands of all time, allowing fans to vie for control of AC/DC’s most iconic albums and international locations.
Custom game board features 22 iconic AC/DC albums and locations, 6 collectible tokens.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Ruinous
description:
Players use custom dice as pawns to move around a modular hexagonal board with 12 action spaces. When landing on a particular space, the player may acquire an action card from that space. If all cards have been taken, the player may capture the piece of the board itself, leaving fewer spaces for the other players to traverse.

When a player moves through a space that already has an opponent's pawn, the opponent launches an ambush. If the opponent has a higher power level (indicated on the face of the die), the opponent may steal a victory point. However, there are also opportunities for the active player to attack as well. Action cards can be used to alter the face of the die, changing the movement points and power level of the player's pawn.

The game ends at the end of the round in which either all "soul shard" cards (acquired by making a circuit of the board) or "destiny markers" (victory point tokens) are gone from the supply. The player(s) with the most victory points wins.

name: Sheila Shark
description: In Sheila Shark, the little fish are splashing in the coral reef when suddenly Sheila, the little girl shark, comes swimming along! Luckily, though, Tinto the octopus is nearby. Can the players manage to spoil Sheila's meal with Tinto's help?

name: Sobriety Test
description: Can you recite "Twinkle, Twinkle Little Star" backward? Can you name all twelve signs of the zodiac while hammered out of your mind? Can you do a curtsy while balancing a ball on your fist? Influenced by the tests issued to those who may have had tee many martoonies, Sobriety Test is a hilarious and raucous game that will have friends reeling just to prove they're totally "with it." This game will challenge memory, speech, and composure, and that's with or without drinking!
mechanics: Acting, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Turn Order: Time Track

name: Fidelitas: The Hunting Lodge Promo
description:
Set up: Place this location off to the side of the play area, apart from the regular locations.

Special Location Ability: Discard a card here to steal a card from any player with more than 2 cards. Do not draw at the end of the turn. Cards played here are not added to the discard pile before reshuffling the Virtus deck.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Medieval

name: ウォッチャ (WOCHA)
description:
User summary
ウォッチャ (WOCHA) is a word game based on the traditional Japanese word game for children called しりとり (Shiritori) which literally means 尻 (buttock) 取り (grabbing). Essentially, you must make a new word (nouns only) using the last character of the previous. For example: ねこ > こま > まほう > うきよえ > えかき and so on. The game has some other simple rules to keep it controlled.

Wocha follows the pattern of Shiritori with picture cards. Each card has a complex picture that can be interpreted many ways, much as Dixit does. Players arrange ten image cards so that everyone can see them easily. Reveal one new image card from the deck to start the chain, then race to decide which one of the ten images can join the first revealed card, explaining how the two cards link together.

Each time a card is moved from the common area to link to the chain, a replacement card is drawn. Each player has four coloured cubes, and drops a cube onto a card when they make a successful link. It is allowed to revise the explanation of the chain by re-intepreting or re-using earlier cards. If a player can make a convincing argument, they can replace the previous player's cube with their own. The first player to dispose of their four cubes is the winner.

If a player makes a rather dubious interpretation on a card image, the game pauses and the players vote thumbs up or down whether to allow it. It is important to follow the rules of the word game. So in the example shown on the blog linked below, the start card was considered as たいよう (太陽 taiyou / sun) and the next card as うま (馬 uma / horse (there is a horse in the car!)), thus chaining with う. Now the current key letter would be ま from うま.

The new card drawn from the deck is a Matryoshka (マトリョーシカ). That would form a chain from うま. Then マトリョーシカ is linked by カッパ (kappa / a Yo-kai, folklore monster). Now that the key letter is パ, when you look back at that first "horse" card, that vehicle might be a パトカー (police car). This lets the player bump the blue cube off and place their own.

Publisher's summary

"Now that you mentioned it, it sure does look so." Associative skills and attentiveness is the key to this new picto-Shiritori game. The rules are simple.

Open 10 cards to form the community cards area, and give each player 4 colored tokens. Then draw 1 card from the deck, and open as the starting key card. Now, let the picture Shiritori begin!

From the 10 community cards, find a picture that can form a Shiritori-chain from the starting card. Found a good card? Call "WOCHA!"

The caller places the card next to the first card to form a chain, and places their token on the placed card. This newly placed card would be the new key. Now the players have to find a community card that can form a new Shiritori chain from the new key. Continue this procedure, and the one who gets rid of all of their tokens is the winner. But beware! The previously used cards may be reused to form a new chain. When done, the color token that was on the card would be removed and returned to the original player. So act quickly, and get rid of all your tokens before anyone attempts to return them back to you!

「言われてみれば、たしかに見える。」
連想力と発見力。新感覚の絵しりとりゲーム。
ウォッチャのルールはとってもカンタン。

全員が共通で使用する10枚のカードを机に並べ、各プレイヤーには4つのカラーコマが渡されます。
あとは、絵でしりとりをします。
山札から１枚カードをめくり、そのカードにチェーン（繋がり）出来そうなカードを場に並んだ10枚から探します。
見つけた人は「WOCHA!（ウォッチャ！）」と叫びましょう。
その人は先ほどのカードの右隣に、自分がキーワードを見つけたカードを置き、さらにその上に自分のカラーコマを置きます。
ゲームは先ほどチェーンされたカードの続きで引き続き行います。
これを繰り返し、手持ちのカラーコマ4つを誰よりも早くなくした人が勝利です。
ただし！すでに誰かが先ほどチェーンしたカードは本人以外が再度使用でき、もしそのカードを誰かが使用すると、先ほどカラーコマをせっかく置いていたのに使用された瞬間、元のプレイヤーのもとに戻ってきてしまうのです。
他のプレイヤーにカラーコマを戻される前に早く４つを手放してしまいましょう。

name: Take a Penny
description:
Take a Penny is played over a series of rounds in which players will secretly choose 1 of 8 actions from the their action card. After all players have made their selections, everyone will reveal their chosen action simultaneously and proceed to resolve them in order. Players cannot take the same action in consecutive rounds which adds to the strategic decision making required to out think their opponents.

You can take two from the pot or only one and block others from taking any but you leave yourself open to others that might take from you. Fake out everyone by returning one to the pot and on the next round by taking two.

The winner is decided once all of the pennies have been taken from the pot. Whoever has the most without being tied wins unless one player manages to shoot the moon and give away all of theirs.`

Take a Penny is a small, fit in your pocket, microgame consisting of 4 square action cards and 4 square bank cards as well as 15 penny tokens.
mechanics: Push Your Luck, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Name Chase:  Musical Icons
description:
From the publisher's website:

Players and teams try to name famous singers, bands, composers, and musicians given a series of clues. If you guess the name on the first and most challenging clue, you get 20 points. If you guess the name on the fourth and easiest clue, you get 5 points. The first team or player to 300 points wins the game. Over 500 famous names.

name: Presidential Knife Fight
description:
Description from the publisher:

Clones of the former Presidents of the United States battle it out to become the Supreme President of These United States! Each body at your feet and every turn around the arena is another vote in your pocket. Get rid of the opposing Presidents by killing them, corrupting them, or having them dragged away kicking and screaming. Survive the carnage by dodging, bribing, and making treaties with your opponents. Your own President may be lost in the fight, but another will always rise up to take their place.

Presidential Knife Fight brings long-dead Presidents back to life for ruthless combat and historical satire in a card game for 3-6 players. The first 43 Presidents- George Washington through George W. Bush, are all represented in card form, each with a unique ability based on their time in office.

Each player begins the game with 3 President cards and gets to choose which order to play them. Maybe George Washington to go first, then Bill Clinton to escape every danger, and clean up with Teddy Roosevelt, the unstoppable killing machine. Gain votes by killing opposing Presidents, surviving a full turn around the table, or through special abilities. Get 5 votes to win the game and become Supreme President of These United States!

Each turn, a player gets 3 actions which they can spend on stabbing their enemies, drawing cards, playing cards, or using their presidential ability; allowing them to build their turn as offensively or defensively as they'd like. Presidents can die from wounds or be thrown out of office from corruption, but dead players re-enter the fight with a new President at the start of their next turn, ensuring no one is out for too long. Players use a shared deck of Action cards, filled with Attacks to kill your enemies, Reactions to keep you alive, and Executive Actions to change up the game. Steal someone's cards with the Patriot Act, have your Scapegoat take the fall for you, or rig the re-election to make sure you never lose!
categories: Card Game, Educational, Fighting, Humor, Political
mechanics: Action Points, Take That, Variable Player Powers

name: Ninja All-Stars: Tengu
description:
Tengu is a mercenary ronin for Ninja All-Stars. Ronin bring potent new abilities to a player’s team that are entirely unique to them. As mercenaries, ronin may be used by any player, on any team. This makes ronin invaluable assets for every team, regardless of clan, since they may be used to supplement a team’s weaknesses in battle or further augment their strengths.
Of the many magical creatures and peoples that inhabit Kagejima, the Tengu are among the most enigmatic. For centuries, these strange creatures would barter or trade their magical and martial skills to the competing clans or war bands. Sometimes they did so for gold or shiny baubles, and sometimes for whispers of love from a beautiful woman, the first wail of a newborn, or thirty stems of saffron. Since the start of the Moonlight Tournament, more tengu have offered their services more often, and increasingly for stranger payments. Though many find this curious, or even ominous, few are unwilling to at least try and meet the price.

Highlights:

Introduces Unique Abilities
Fully Assembled Model
Mystical and Magical Mercenary Ronin
categories: Adventure, Collectible Components, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Fighting, Humor, Miniatures, Sports, Video Game Theme

name: Carps & Angsty Manatee: Texas Edition (fan expansion for Cards Against Humanity)
description:
Texas: From the outside looking in, you can't understand it.

From the inside looking out, you can't explain it.

We dove deep into our Texas roots to create this raunchy, Texas-themed expansion pack. If you love Cards Against Humanity, you will love this unofficial expansion.

We took special care to ensure that all cards played well with other expansions and that the cards are the same professional size, finish, and quality as other decks. Carps & Angsty Manatee: Texas Edition includes 150 brand new, original cards (125 absurdly Texan white cards & 25 ridiculously Texan black cards).

100% compatible with CAH cards and other third party expansions.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fan Expansion, Humor, Mature / Adult, Party Game

name: Oh! Yummy Burger to Go!
description:
In your town is a very famous burger restaurant where many people go for its delicious burgers. In the diner, they have not only a variety of flavors, but also customized burgers for those who want to make their own. Because the burger restaurant is so famous, a huge line of people is always in front of the diner. If you want to get your burger as quickly as possible, you'd better line up early as it's the only way you can share the flavor of this burger with your family and friends.

In Oh! Yummy Burger to Go!, one of the players will make a burger first, then all players play a card from their hands. According to the cards, some players are able to discard the card. When someone runs out the hand, that player wins the game automatically.
mechanics: Pattern Building, Player Elimination, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Cloud Hoppers
description:
Once upon a time
In a distant galaxy,there is a planet called Cytoma.Cytoma's neighbouring planets have been trying to get a magical flower,Cyta. Take on the role of the aliens and begin your Cyta quest. Master Subtraction & Addition along the way!
We have done extensive research to develop this unique game board. It comes with a special 10-faced die and built-in challenges to provide you with hours of fun.At the same time, you’ll be mastering subtraction like no one else.

Skills Addressed
• Forward thinking
• Strategic Planning
• Patience & Perseverance
• Flexibility

Practice jump
12x more practice than traditional class time and worksheets
At Logic Roots, we are passionate about Math and work with the vision of Reinventing how kids practice Math through gamification of its concepts. Our Board Games, Card Games and Apps are widely used by top schools and homeschooling parents to help their boys and girls fall in love with Math. These games are best used for Learning, Education and gifting purposes for children.

Target group
Grade 1 and above || 6 years and above

How it works
Players select the aliens and roll the 10-faced dice.Subtract the number obtained from 50 and continue to do so till the aliens land in a safe zone.Add and subtract as per the rules and the player to first reach the Cyta flower wins.Players have to use subtraction and addition skills extensively to win. Combined with special 10 faced dice, these cleverly designed game rules work to increase the amount of practice and fun at the same time!

Contents of the box
• 8 aliens(2 aliens per planet)
• Special 10 faced dice with numbers from 0 to 9
• 1 Gameboard
• 1 Rule book

name: Gnome's Lunch
description:
These gnomes have an unusually big appetite for their size! Connect as many gnome tiles to the pizza tiles as you can to collect the most points. Beware of the dragons — they scare away the gnomes... unless the gnomes team up against the dragons. Surrounded, the dragons will have no other option but to flee!

Gnome’s Lunch is a minimalistic board game with 1-minute rules and a very rich gameplay: tactics, bluff, player interaction and lots of fun!

—description from the publisher

name: Crane & Wave: Samurai at War
description:
A card driven Wargame, winning several awards in the 2018 Wargame PnP Contest:
3rd Place: Best Overall Game
2nd Place: Best Artwork
2nd Place: Best Overall Rules
2nd Place: Best 2+ Player Game
2nd Place: Best Short/Quick/Small Game
2nd Place: Best New Designer
3rd Place: Most Original Concept

SUMMARY
Japan in 1567, at the height of the Sengoku Jidai – the Age of Warring States. Powerful Samurai families each have conquered large parts of Japan, and the days of the last Ashikaga Shogun in Kyoto are numbered. By land and sea, many more battles will befall the already war-torn country. And soon, one of the many Daimyōs – the Samurai Warlords – might unite enough regions of Japan under his banner, to call himself the new Shogun. Who will be the first to quench his thirst for power, and start a dynasty to shape Japan for the centuries to come?

GOAL
Become the greatest of the Samurai, by controlling Kyoto and large parts of Japan.

GAMEPLAY
Players draw cards to place armies, attack or fortify provinces and send out agents to sabotage their enemies. The more powerful players become, the more cards they may draw, but the less control they have over which cards to keep.

Every now and then, an Event Card will bring change to the war. The biggest of which is the arrival of the Europeans, who bring firearms and Christianity with them, opening up new possibilities to the players.
categories: Civil War, Pike and Shot, Print & Play, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Area Majority / Influence, Open Drafting

name: Awkward Hugs
description:
Awkward Hugs is the game of connections, questions, and consequences! Two players are locked in a hug by the included hug belts, and another player asks questions like, "Would you swim with sharks?" or "Are you a binge watcher?" Both huggers must answer the same way or they'll get a hilarious consequence card such as slow dancing or standing like a flamingo. Match three questions correctly to unlock the hug.

Game includes two hug belts, two keys, a deck of questions cards, a deck of consequences cards, and a game guide.

name: Journey: Wrath of Demons – Jiangshi Coffin Set
description:
The infamous Chinese hopping zombie, known for their stiff gait, Invade the Kingdom of Terra!

This set contains all you need to add the Jiangshi to your existing Bull Demon Quests. It contains highly detailed unpainted plastic miniatures, cards and rules, together with 2 brand new Quests with a new story line. Multiple Jiangshi Coffin Sets can be used together to create a Chinese Zombie Horde.

—description from the publisher

name: Farming Dice
description:
Farming Has Never Been So Dicey!

Roll the dice. Send some carrots to the LEFT. Send some apples to the RIGHT. Send some wheat to the BANK. And take back your broccoli. Just don't let anyone control your entire crop or you're out of the game! Farming has never been so dicey!

Object of Farming Dice is to be the last farmer with tokens. Farming Dice requires some strategy and a little luck of the dice. The roll of the dice determines which crops to move, but the player decides where the crop goes – and if you play it strategically, you can eliminate a farmer from the game.

—description from the publisher

name: Covid-19
description:
If you were able to survive this scourge and still have air in your lungs, try playing this challenging 40-day quarantine print & play game with strategy and patience.

The game is very simple. You will start a quarantine due to the coronavirus and you must take care of yourself. During the game you must acquire food to live every day. You must get money to buy a mask and alcohol gel and thus be protected. And you will need to stay home as well as a safe conduit if you need to move.
mechanics: Action/Event, Dice Rolling, Paper-and-Pencil, Solo / Solitaire Game, Trading

name: Pestilence
description:
Pestilence is a roll and write, print at home board game set in 17th century Europe, at the height of the Plague. With the city locked down, and swarms of rats infesting every street, the civilans are left to an almost certain death. There is, however, an underground network asssisting people’s escape. You must gain supplies and bolster your reputation to convince the network to help you escape, all while avoiding the watchful eye of the king’s men!

Just grab a pencil, print out a board, and you're ready to go!
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Paper-and-Pencil, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Gurms
description:
Your game table is about to become infected with Gurms! Don’t worry though, coming down with a case of these cuties is a good thing! In this tile-matching strategy game for kids and adults, your mission is to complete as many pictures of the gurms as possible.

—description from the publisher

On your turn, place your tile touching at least one other tile. All edges that are touching must match, and white can't match with anything, not even other white edges. Match at least two edges to immediately take another turn.

Every edge that matches will create a Gurm. Your goal is to make connected groups of your own Gurm type, either side-to-side or corner-to-corner. Each Gurm in a group is worth as many points as the size of the group! When there are no more tiles to be placed, the player with the most points wins.

name: Thermopylae: The Hot Gates
description:
Commonly known as the Stand of the 300, Thermopylae was an amazing battle. The Persian Empire troops, led by Xerxes I, faced 300 Greek forces, led by the Spartans, led by Leonidas. Are you able to hold off the Persians? Are you able to defeat them before the flanking forces attack from the surrounding hills? Stand and become the object of legends!

Background:

(480 BC) The Battle of Thermopylae was fought between the Achaemenid Persian Empire under Xerxes I and an alliance of Greek city-states led by Sparta under Leonidas I.The engagement at Thermopylae occurred simultaneously with the Battle of Artemisium: between July and September 480 BC. Lasting over the course of three days, it was one of the most prominent battles of both the second Persian invasion of Greece which, under Xerxes I was a delayed response to the failure of the first Persian invasion which had been initiated by Darius I and ended in 490 BC by an Athenian-led Greek victory at the Battle of Marathon. Xerxes had amassed a massive land and naval force, and set out to conquer all of Greece. The Athenian politician and general Themistocles proposed that the allied Greeks block the advance of the Persian army at the pass of Thermopylae.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Events, Simulation, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: You're Getting Old
description:
Have you ever scrolled Spotify’s top 100 list and thought to yourself, “Who the hell are these people?” or said, “8pm is too late to start a movie”? If so, then gather around with your side parts, skinny jeans, and craft beers because it’s time to play “You’re Getting Old”, a party game that proves age is just a number... but sometimes that number is higher than you'd like it to be.

Each turn, a card is drawn with both an “old” and "redeem" prompt. If you've said or done what's listed on the "old" prompt, you move your avocado piece down one space on your “path to getting old” card. Congratulations, you're one step closer to the finish line... or should we say "the end of the line."

But don't worry, there's a glimmer of hope! If you've said or done what's listed on the ""redeem"" prompt, you get to move back a space. It's a small victory, but it's a reminder that you still have some youth left in you.

The player who reaches the end of the path first is the loser, and the player closest to the start wins, but let's be real, you're all losers in this game.

You're Getting Old is perfect for your next game night with friends or family, a party, or social event!

—description from the publisher

name: Crazy Alias
description:
There are many cards, each card has 6 words written on it. Each word has a number, from 1 to 6. Words are various - from very easy to very hard. Some are made of several words defining one thing (example: "Silver Medal"). There is also a board with tiles. Each tile is marked with number from 1 to 6.

So, players play 2 vs.2. Each team gets a figure representing it on the board. Their goal is to get through the board. Each time a figure stops one team member must take a card and not show it to other team member. After that a sand clock (also included) is set. The Player must get the other team member to say the word that is written on card by using sentences to describe the word. For example, if the word is "Silver Medal", a player can say "something that a sportsmen wins at the Olympic games". But if other team member says just "Medal", it isn't correct. Then the first player must further define what the hint might be. Second player can answer as often as he/she wants until the time runs out. If time runs out or first player accidentally uses the word which is written in card, the team looses a turn.

This Alias is weird and crazy. The words doesn't make any sense, but you still need to explain these. Can you do it?
categories: Humor, Party Game, Racing, Word Game
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Team-Based Game

name: Ataturk!
description:
(From the game flyer)

Ataturk is a simulation of the War for Turkish Independence fought between May, 1919 and October, 1922. The game is for two players, one representing the Allies (British, French and Greeks), Caliphate Turks, Armenians, Kurds and Soviets, and the other player the Turkish Nationalist Army, White Russian Volunteer Army, Georgia National Army, and Azeribaijan National Army.

Ataturk Contains:

one 11"x17" map
over 250 counters
one 20 page rulebook
various player aids

name: Sharks Are Wild
description: Sharks are Wild reinforces sequencing: counting both forwards and backwards. Each player starts with a number 5 “starter card” on the table and an open hand of five cards (numbers 0-4, 6-9, and wild). On his turn, a player draws a card, then either plays a card into his sequence or discards. Once a player has achieved a sequence of five cards (including the starter card), they receive a coin, discard the sequence, and start again. A Shark card is wild, and may be played anywhere in a sequence. Playing a Shark also rewards the player with an additional coin. Advanced play includes Octopus cards to steal from another player’s sequence and Dolphin cards to block the steal. First player to receive five coins wins.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Educational, Number
publishers: Hoyle Products, The United States Playing Card Company

name: Rasant
description: Players play cards in colors matching 12 wooden cars (3 cars in each color) which are placed in a line behind a single black pace car. Players must play a card in the same color as the first card played. The player playing the highest card in that color after all other players have passed then moves the car of that color farthest back in the line, along with all cars behind it, in reverse order to the front of the line, scoring 1 point for each car moved. If the pace car is among those moved, it does not score but rather doubles the points for all other cars that move up.

name: Fuh Gedda Boudit
description:
From the box:

The BOSS of Board Games!

So . . . you wanna be a Wise Guy? Fuh gedda boudit!

One minute you're riding high and running the board and then . . . WHACK . . . you're swimmin' with the fishes. This game turns on a dime. Try to be the first player to get two of your members into the Pinky Ring Social Club to become "Made Men", and you WIN!

Not a Monopoly knock-off, but has some similar mechanics. Good light mafia game.

name: DEADCERT: London
description:
The game is a completely new breed of Detective Card Game that is based on realistic detective processes, characters and storylines, all set in London during the first half of 2015.

Crime scenes are real London locations and historical facts are blended with fiction. 125 different murder scenarios are waiting to be solved. The game encourages the use of "deductive and abductive reasoning" to assist in reducing the suspect list from 37 to 10 prime suspects, to ultimately identify the only possible killer. The objective of the game has two parts, concerned with discovering the identity of the culprit and having the incriminating evidence to hand!

The game has 3 play formats - OPENplay (2-6), COVERTplay (2-5) or SOLOplay - and has Career, Group and Co-Op variants that provide ample choice in the way the game is played.

The game set comes complete with; 5 Evidence Packs (labelled, ABCDE) a total of 300 cards; "How to be a Deadcert Detective Guide"; a Detective Checklist Pad (with 30 double sided sheets) and 25 Evidence Bags. Each Evidence Pack contains 3 "evidence types" - Victim; Crime Scene and Time of Death - that are used to define murder cases and provide details of the suspects. When the game set is initially opened, the Evidence Packs are each split into 3 Evidence type Packets and kept securely in their individual evidence bags. This will use 15 of 25 bags provided - more about the remaining bags later...

At the start of a game - or "murder episode" as it is referred to - one of each type of Evidence Packet is selected in order to define the murder mystery to be solved. With 5 Evidence Packs this means there are 5x5x5=125 possible episodes that can be played out. With the crime defined, the 18 suspect cards for each evidence type are shuffled together to form the 54 cards in play. 48 of the cards hold information about the suspects - why they had motive, means or the opportunity to carry out the murder. The other 6 are the Snoop cards which play a slightly different role depending on the format being played, but in essence are used to mix up the game play and enable the transfer of suspect evidence between players (or detectives if you wish to fully embrace the experience).

So what about the extra 10 evidence bags? Well 1 is a genuine spare, the other 9 however (and the extra compartment with the game set tray) enable you to safely store up to 3 expansion packs (labelled, FGH) sold separately. These Expansion Packs provide extra victims, crime scenes and times of death to the London mix and interlink with the existing packs. Not only do they increase the number of murder episodes possible, they do so exponentially. If all 3 Expansion Packs are added, 125 episodes expand to a potential 512.

The structure of the game is unique, and is the first of it's kind to provide multiple realistic crime mysteries with a pure card game format - no solution book is required, the murderer is simply the only suspect to have had motive, means and opportunity.

Unlike many card games, it does not lean heavily on the graphics. This, although potentially unpopular with many, is a deliberate move to help focus on the evidence, the textual content of the suspect cards. Font sizing, colouring and new sentences starting on new lines, has all been done to make the reading of the cards as comfortable as possible, to the widest audience as possible. Graphics play an important role in distinguishing the 3 card types, but that is their key role.

The final aspect of the game, that is only set to emerge after playing a few episodes, is the detail and integrity of all the characters that are woven together through the multiple storylines. Any information gathered about a victim or suspect may come in use in future investigations and nothing learnt will be contradicted later by another card. In short, the interwoven stories, events and relationships have as much integrity as the knowledge that you have identified the killer correctly. There are no miscarriages of justice with Deadcert.

Please note: The 15+ age advisory is for reason of content in the detail of the crimes committed, and is not associated with the difficulty of the game play.

name: Yesss!: Promo cards
description:
This expansion contains 15 new cards for Yesss!
Add these cards to the base game.

This expansion is given out by the publisher at conventions.

name: King of the Hill
description: Players take turns moving their marble to the top of the plastic mountain. If a marble lands on a hole, it is dropped in and comes out in a random fashion at a lower level cave. Marbles making it to the crown on top are dropped in, and will usually fall through to a lower level, but if the crown pops up, the player wins. Instead of a die, the game has a unique hourglass shaped teeter-totter piece which, when flipped, causes a small marble (keeping with the marble theme) to fall through a series of pegs to one of 6 slots at the bottom marked with numbers.

name: Siggi Safeknacker
description:
There are four safes in different colors on the table, consisting of two card stacks; one open one and one draw pile. The players take turns rolling a die to determine a color, then look at the open card of the safe in the corresponding color. Now they must guess whether the next card they will draw from the safe's draw pile will be higher or lower than the current open card of the safe. If the guess is right, the player takes the open card(s) and replaces it by the drawn one. If a guess is wrong, however, the drawn card is added to the open card stack of the safe. Also, a player who makes a wrong guess loses all unprotected cards in front of him/her. Instead of rolling the die, s/he can also choose to protect one's loot and put it in a bag.
When all cards have been distributed, the player with the highest loot is the winner.

name: Puzzle Battle
description:
The object of the game is to be the first to complete the puzzle.

There are two similar puzzles for both players but beware although the puzzles seems to be identical all pieces fit only one of the puzzles.
publishers: Blue Orange Games, Editions RoseBud, Lautapelit.fi, Vennerød Forlag AS

name: The Man in the Moon
description:
A board of twenty-five squares and two sets of twelve counters in contrasting colors compose The Man in the Moon.
The object of the game is to avoid becoming the "Man in the Moon".
The first player places one of her counters on any space on the board, except the center square. Then the second player places one of his counters on any space on the board, except the center square, and so on until the twenty-four counters have been placed, leaving the center square empty.
The first player now moves one of her counters to the center square. The second player then has his turn, and each then plays in succession. The counters may be moved orthogonally, but not diagonally.
When a player flanks one or more opposing counters between two of his own, they are all captured as long as there are no intervening empty spaces. (Similar to Othello's flanking conversion.)
Counters may be captured only by a moving player. If one or more counters are caught between two opposing counters while the counters are being placed on the board, it does not count as a capture. Capturing does not begin until all twenty-four counters have been placed on the board.
If a player cannot move because her counters are blocked, the other player must continue moving until the blockade is raised. Then the blocked player takes her turn and play goes on as before. This rule also applies to the first move of the game.
The player who succeeds in reducing her opponent to one counter wins the game, the single counter left on the board becoming the "Man in the Moon".

Online Play


Super Duper Games
mechanics: Grid Movement, Square Grid, Variable Set-up

name: Flip Flap Flop
description: A card game of 48 cards with every card having the picture of a cartoony face on it. The face, however, is slightly different on each card and there are eight sets of different expressions with six cards of each expression. The cards are dealt to all players face down to make a deck. Each turn all players simultaneously reveal the top card of their deck. If a player notices three identical faces he yells out "Flip Flap Flop". If correct, that player takes the three identical cards. Unclaimed cards are left on the table. A player who makes an incorrect call may not call on the following round but must play a card as usual. When one player has six sets of FLIP FLAP FLOP cards, the game ends. Players count their cards and the player with the most cards wins.

name: Hauberk
description:
Hauberk: The Ultimate Game of Intellectual Cunning, is how this game is billed. The side of the box reads "A game of ruses and rescue." And according to the rule book, the objective is:

To rescue the Princess by entering the castle where she is located after you have become a Player Knight. Though you are courageous as a Squire, and possess the ability to locate the Princess, you lack the power to save her. Only as a Player Knight may you accomplish your task.

It appears that a player can accumulate artifacts and cards to progress towards being a "player knight." Then if he or she can enter the castle (where the princess is), that person wins.

Seems much like a 1970s fantasy video game combined with The Mystic Wood.

Was once on the Games Magazine Top 100 games list.

name: Pac Man Magnetic Maze
description: Pac Man Magnetic Maze from Tomy is a physical implementation of the Pac-Man video game, utilizing a maze on a tilting plane, controlled by a mechanical joystick. Pac-Man has a magnet on his head which he uses to grab fruit as he passes under them on the board. The metal gates that hold the fruit may be placed in different positions on the board, providing variety in each game. Two ghosts rove about the board, moving as Pac-Man does, with the tilt of the plane. Each of the three characters has a steel ball bearing in its "foot" to permit it to travel freely about the maze. The ghosts and Pac-Man have opposite-polarity magnets for "ears", which permits the ghosts to capture Pac-Man. A timer sets the pace, and with the clock ever ticking, the player must try to snag all three fruits without allowing the ghosts to catch Pac-Man.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Children's Game, Video Game Theme

name: Bolt 'n' Stein
description: Players try to collect three lightning bolts while navigating the spaces on the Frankenstein monster. Players try to knock others off by landing on special squares and bringing that section of the monster to life. The winner must have three lightning bolts and bring the monster to life!
categories: Children's Game, Horror, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Calcula
description: You have a board of 20*20 and each player gets 5 numbers. Now you have to make a sum (or something else) with your numbers and the characters freely available next to the board. For instead: 5+2=7 or 9/3=3. Your result are the points you score. Next player starts with one of your numbers. A lot like scrabble but with numbers.

name: Snapshots Across America
description: Win by being the first to visit 7 different tourist attractions across America that are pictured on the cards.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Set Collection

name: Voitto Kotiin
description: There are 936 words and 936 sayings and players take turns drawing these while others are trying to guess correctly.

name: Super 5 Salto
description:
Follow up to 5 Alive with new special cards and a different way to get lives.

Players take turns playing cards and adding up the total - you want to take the total over 21 so you gain a life. First Player with 5 lives wins!

name: Exodus from Egypt
description:
Box back:

When you move your two pieces across the River Jordan into the Promised Land you WIN! Spectacular images light the path of the Israelites’ epic journey in the Exodus.

On your turn you will draw a card and play a card. Some cards give you a choice of possible moves, but what really adds to the number of possible moves is that you can move any piece on the board.

name: Kurzer Prozess: Krimi-Kartenspiel
description: A few pretty bad villains are sitting on the Anklagebank, and what they should have on the scoreboard: theft, falsification, burglary, extortion, and even murder! But in Kurzer Prozess everyone tries to push the responsibility for these crimes on others. Will the crooks get away with it?

name: Калибр .45 (Caliber .45)
description:
Caliber .45 is a game about wild west, cowboys, caravans and trains robbery, skirmishes and betrayals, all for the sake of the cherished million. Caliber .45 serves great for party board gaming. It can be played against each other, or divided into teams.

The essence of the game

Each player receives a cowboy card, then the cowboys take turns arming themselves, collecting cards from a common deck with weapons. One of the players, realizing that he is ready to go into the business, notifies other players and they can decide either to join the raid or refuse. Cowboys-robbers draw out a card of their target - it can be a stagecoach, train, bank or other card that brings money - then they will need to get rid of security, by spending their weapons. After that cowboys begin to divide the loot, which most often leads to a shootout, the winner receives the whole jackpot. In the loot deck there are not only trains and stagecoaches, there are also indians, a sheriff and other misfortunes that can ruin a robbery, send robbers to prison, or even kill an entire gang at once.

The cowboy's task is to earn his million. The one whose extraction brought this money becomes the winner.

You can play the game alone against all or teams, teaming up in pairs, in which case you will need to collect a million for two.

Who is this game for?

The board game is suitable for parties, table feasts in canyons and deserts, behind the bar of the saloon or family evenings on the farm. You can give it to children and adults, especially suitable for those who like simple games for the company, cowboy themes and spaghetti westerns, competitive card fillers, mustangs and armadillos.

—description from the publisher
categories: American West, Bluffing, Card Game, Fighting
mechanics: Hand Management, Take That, Team-Based Game

name: Pinguflip
description:
Penguin Flip

When mom penguin starts handing out fish popsicles, the penguin kids race from ice floe to ice floe to earn their treats. But whenever they jump off an ice floe, it always flips to the other side and reveals a new surprise. The first player to complete three laps with their penguin kid wins the game.

—description from the publisher

name: Mini Town
description:
You stand in an empty field and survey the land around. “This will be Mini Town!” you announce to the birds dramatically. As self-elected mayor, it’s your job to oversee development of the new town. Build your infrastructure and services to best serve the community and, of course, to gain the most points!

Mini Town is a family game for any number of players that plays in around 20 minutes.

Play is simultaneous: each player plays at the same time on their own scoresheet. Each player chooses how to use the rolls of two dice. Other players may make other decisions. One die shows the location (row or column) for the construction. Choose from any of the available squares in the row and column. The other die shows the type of construction (road, park, house, library cafe or shop) that can be built in one square. Each player draws their chosen construction type within their chosen location. When all players have used the dice roll, re-roll for the next turn.

The pad comes with 50 scoresheets.

-description from designer

name: Wineopoly
description: Pop the cork off any gathering with WINEOPOLY! Players buy favorite wines, collect bunches of grapes and trade them in for decanters. Sounds easy enough but add Import Taxes and serving faux pas and it becomes a little more difficult and a lot more fun! Learn while you play! Each deed back contains wine descriptors and fun facts about each wine. It's all fun and games until you're sent to the Wine Cellar to age-then you're out of the game for three turns. So choose your token (wine bottle, cork, wine glass, cheese, grapes, or a carafe) and advance to CHEERS! Who knows? You may be elected president of the wine club or you may be penalized for serving obtrusively malodorous cheese!
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Stock Holding, Trading
publishers: Late for the Sky Production Company

name: Reader's Digest Word Power
description:
This board game from Reader's Digest puts your knowledge of words to the test in your quest to become the Word Power champion. But watch out - Wild Cards, Power Cards or the roll of the dice will move you along, set you back or even help foil your opponents.

Contents:
Game Board
700 Challenge Cards (2100 challenges in total)
50 Power Cards
30 Wild Cards
6 game pieces
1 dice and dice-throwing cup

name: Alphabet Race
description:
Try to name a word which begins with the letter A and with B and then with C - so on through to Z. That won't be too difficult! But when the word you name has also to belong to a particular group or type of thing, the whole thing becomes much more tricky!

A word game. On a board with 20 letters from A to Z, the players try to move to the last letter by finding words. The players get cards with a generic term and have to think of a word, which falls under this term. In the beginning the players start with the letter A. They have 30 seconds of time. If they cannot come up with a letter the card goes to the next player on the left, who now has to think of a proper word. If the player finds a suitable word, he moves to the next letter. As soon as one player reaches the letter Z the game ends.

A fun language skills game for Ages 7 - 12.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Die Baumeister des Krimsutep
description:
Pharaoh Krimsutep has called, and his master builders have come.
You and your fellow players erect magnificent palaces, impressive obelisks and design wonderful oases for the great Pharaoh Krimsutep. You plan your designs well, but be careful to play your material procurement cards correctly. Who will win in the contest of the Pharaoh's favor?

name: Suitors
description:
You are in love; it can't be helped. It is one of those things that happens to everyone. The Problem, in this case , is that you aren't the only one going after you Paramour. These usurpers will do anything to take the person you care about the most away from you. So, go forth using all the Power, Money and Love at your disposal to defeat all those who would stand between you and your only One. Prove you are the best Suitor.
This is a unique trick taking game where the strongest cards have the least points. It also includes some special 'power' cards that allow you to do interesting actions.

name: Ligretto Twist
description:
Ligretto Twist features the familiar Ligretto game play, with players trying to rid themselves of cards from their personal stack as quickly as possible by playing them to shared central stacks. The twist comes in that players must lay a hand on top of the card they most recently played, and they can't use that hand again until they lay a card on another stack – thereby imprisoning that second hand until the first hand plays again. What's more, no other player can lay down cards on a covered stack, so everyone will be fighting to slap stacks first. Finally, unlike other Ligretto games, these cards have only colors – no numbers.

When a player plays the final card in his personal stack, the round ends and all other players score one point for each card remaining in their stack. The player with the fewest points after five rounds wins.

name: Five Little Fish
description:
Fish or Frog, what’s hiding under the Lily Pads? It’s a classic game of matching with a clever twist that will keep parents and children guessing. Flip a Lily Pad Card to see which fish you need to catch. Use a Fishing Rod to hook the fish you think will match. Reel it in to reveal its telescoping colored tail. If it’s a match, you keep the catch! Pay close attention! If you flip over Grumpy Frog’s Lily Pad, you throw a fish back. Can you remember which one’s which? Catch the most fish to win!


Place all the Little Fish in the center of the table so the heads face up, and the telescoping tails are tucked inside.
Shuffle the Little Fish so no one knows which one’s which and put the Fishing Rods to the side.
Shuffle the Lily Pad cards and lay them face down around the Little Fish.
The youngest player goes first! Start by turning over a Lily Pad Card of your choice. If the Lily Pad shows a…
Fish – Take a Fishing Rod, choose any one of the Little Fish on the table and hook it with the Fishing Rod. Lift the Little Fish so that everyone can see which colored body falls out from underneath the head.
If it matches the fish shown on the Lily Pad Card, place it down on the table in front of you, making sure to collapse the body back inside its head.
If there is no match, then the Little Fish you chose remains in its current position.

Rainbow Fish – Choose ANY one of the Little Fish and drag it in front of you. Do NOT lift it up and reveal the color of the body. If there are no Little Fish in the middle of the table, then you may take one Little Fish sitting in front of another player, careful to not reveal the body of the Little Fish.
Grumpy Frog – Bad Luck! Push one of your Little Fish from in front of you back in the middle of the table. Do NOT lift it up and reveal the colored body inside. If you don’t have a Little Fish in front of you then nothing happens and your turn is over.

If you turn over a Lily Pad card that reveals a Little Fish that you think is already in front of you, then you can use a Fishing Rod to lift it up and show the match. If you’re correct, you may turn over another Lily Pad Card and have another turn. If you do not reveal the matching Little Fish, your turn is over.
The game ends when all the Lily Pad Cards have been discarded. The player with the most fish in front of them wins! If it’s a tie, players will check the tail tips of their Little Fish – the player with the highest number on their Little Fish wins the game!

name: Ice Blocks
description:
from Comment:

This is a simple abstract strategy game somewhat reminiscent of Connect Four. Place cubes to form a pyramid, score points for having cubes of your color in a row, horizontal or diagonal. Bigger rows are worth an increasing number of points.

name: Hungry Henry
description:
Henry, a large plastic bird, swivels on his perch as players attempt to feed various items into his large, hinge-like beak.

Each turn, one item MUST be fed to Henry until it either remains in his beak or causes another object to fall out. Fallen objects are added to the player's pile of items.

The first player to successfully feed all their items to Henry wins the game.

name: Alva
description:
An early game from the designer of Hey, That's My Fish!

The game is played on the intersections of a 9×9 grid, each player receives 34 pieces in their color.

A player's turn consists of either
1) Moving 1 piece to a neighboring empty point (optional), followed by placing a new piece on any empty point. (required)

or

2) Taking pieces by jumping over horizontal or vertical lines of their opponent's pieces. If this is possible, this must be done instead of moving/placing pieces via option 1.

Lines with 2 pieces cannot be jumped over, but any other amount can be. The jumping piece must continue jumping until no more jumps are possible. After each jump, the opponent's pieces are captured and removed from the board. If you capture the same number of pieces that your opponent just captured from you on the preceding turn, the pieces are returned to the opponent and not placed in your captured pile.

The game ends when a player cannot make any legal move. Each player gets one point for each captured opponent's piece, plus one point for each opponent's piece on the outside border of the board. Most points wins.

name: Berenstain Bears Earthsaver Game
description:
Golden game #5080, Berenstain Bears Earthsaver Game, The Clean-It-Up Adventure Game!

Designed by Stan and Jan Berenstain, the object of this game is to win Berenstain Bears #1 Earthsaver Badge by collecting the most trash tokens by the end of the game.

The players spin and moves his/her wagon play piece ahead the number of spaces indicated on the spinner. If the player lands on a space with a trash token, the token is put into the player's wagon. Player's continue around the board collecting trash tokens. The game ends when one player reaches Finish. The player with the most trash tokens wins the game.

"The Berenstain Bears really appreciate it when we clean up their neighborhood. Try to keep your own neighborhood clean, too. Next time you throw something away, please put trash in its place and keep our world clean! Then you'll be a real #1 EARTHSAVER!"

name: Card Golf
description:
This is the successor of the highly successful game of KARGO from the same company, in this edition in the line of the "Double feature Games".

Game consists of 54 illustrated cards: 29 distance cards, 12 putt cards, 1 holed out card and 12 hazard cards. As second feature added is a distance indicator chart and 4 numbered, very tiny golfballs (4 mm diameter).

Object of the game is to get the ball into the Hole in the least number of turns.

Gameplay is the same as in Kargo: Players try to drive their ball and in the meantime to hinder the opponent to do so. Special rules apply for using which wood or iron in certain situations , the same goes for the hazard cards and their counterplays. Driven distances are marked with the golfballs on the indicator chart.
Further added is a list of real golfcourses and their distances to play for the competitors.

name: Monopoly: Here & Now UK Edition
description: The classic Monopoly with unique properties and other elements of the United Kingdom - as voted by its citizens.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: I Spy Memory Game: Travel Edition
description:
Your favorite I Spy Memory Game in a take-along, travel-size version. All new cards for new memory and matching fun! Made your matches? Now solve the 5 new riddles.

The game uses the classic I Spy photography of Walter Wick as the basis for two styles of play. Younger children can simply match the images on two different cards while older players can find the images that correspond to various riddles.

New riddles versus the full-sized edition, but only about a third as many tiles.

name: Monopoly: London – Games to Go
description:
A standard version of monopoly based on the classic London board - Park Lane and Mayfair - but in a small, small box. A portable version of Monopoly, with tiny components.

The cards and money are a bit fiddly, but this is a proper and complete version of Monopoly
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Sky Thieves
description:
Sky Thieves is a steampunk card game. You play as the captain of an airship full of pirates, with the goal of being the first captain to steal 5 treasure. To steal treasure, you have to battle targets like an Iron Automaton, a Fortified Depository, or the Military Police. You can arm your ship with crazy technology like an Astral Tracking System, Semiautonomous Exosuit, or (the old classic) a Death Ray. When your opponents are trying to steal a treasure you'd rather take, you can sabotage them with a Planted Mutineer or some Drugged Rum.

Play is easy to learn, like Munchkin, with strategic depth to keep things interesting, like Race for the Galaxy.
categories: Aviation / Flight, Card Game, Fantasy, Pirates

name: Game Over
description:
Game Over is a tabletop card game set within the realm of the digital gaming world where each player must control 3 characters in order to fight for survival. It is designed for quick and casual gameplay with layers of various strategic elements to keep each round feeling fresh and new.

Players select their characters and then take turns building their inventory by randomly drawing cards from the play deck. Each turn will allow for a player to either equip an item, attack, perform a special ability, use an action card, or redeem gems for special bonuses throughout the round. Knowing your enemies from your allies is imperative as each player can "beat the game" in several different ways. The game is over when a player reaches one of three different win scenarios:

Last Man Standing - Be the last survivor by knocking all other players out of the game
High Score - Be the first to collect 25 bonus points by accumulating gems throughout the round
Quest Complete - Be the first to find the 3 hidden enchanted items within the play deck
categories: Card Game, Party Game, Video Game Theme

name: Snap Attack
description: Snap Attack is a fun and interactive wooden board game for 2-4 players. Each player or team receives 7 powerfully magnetic pucks. The object of the game is to not cause the SNAP ATTACK! Players take turns placing their magnetic pucks on the recessed playing surface while trying not to upset the finely balanced magnetic fields and cause the pucks to snap together. When a player makes a move that causes one or more pucks to snap together–SNAP ATTACK–that player loses the game. When this happens, the player who didn’t cause the SNAP ATTACK is awarded a point.

name: Jackal: The Card Game
description: In this game, each player takes on the role of a pirate who is trying to claim the most treasure. In each round of the game, you will land at a new island where you will use your Action Cards to try and reach the treasure before your opponents do. After 10 islands have been visited, the pirates head to the tavern to tally up their gold. Whoever has the most coins wins!
mechanics: Hand Management, Network and Route Building

name: Raccoon Madness Game
description:
Description from the publisher:

The raccoons are out of control. They’ve diversified into many different forms, morphing into all manner of styles. In Raccoon Madness, you’ll have to be good at bluffing in order to get rid of your cards. Will another player call your bluff?

Players that have no cards won!

Every day we have to decide whether to tell the truth or to tell a lie; sometimes we are afraid of being deceived and we feel ashamed whenever we are caught in a lie. To train our intuition and to enhance our emotion reading skills in a fun environment, we have created “Raccoon Madness Game”.

This game was created by three friends. We have been inspired by Tim Burtons art, old USSR game and Texas Holdem Poker.
categories: Animals, Bluffing, Card Game, Comic Book / Strip, Deduction, Humor, Party Game
mechanics: Hand Management, Player Elimination, Push Your Luck, Take That

name: Hampeltiere: Active Kids
description:
It's a lot of fun for players to show how well they can imitate the actions of their animal friends. Who will be fastest to imitate a spinning chicken or a dancing donkey? And who will manage to arch their back like the cat? But beware: With the tired turtle you all need to stay calm. In each round a different player is the judge, and decides who best imitated the action.

How to play:

In each round one player is the judge and the other players have an "action competition", they copy the movement of the animal on the turned over card as quickly as possible.


Place the stack of cards in front of you so that all other players can see it.
Turn over the top card as quickly as possible.
As the judge you need to decide who took the right action first. This player may move their parrot one field further on the edge of the game board.
When the first player reaches the starting field again with their parrot, the fun action competition is over and they win the game.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Animals, Card Game, Children's Game

name: Szabadulj kvíz
description: Players admire the pyramids on the Mokattam Plateau in Egypt. When entering the great pyramid of Giza, a scary thing happens. The stone slab blocking the entrance to the pyramid closes with a huge bang. Whoever wants to get out of the captivity of the pyramid must answer the questions correctly. The cards feature questions from players on a variety of topics: science, technology, flora and fauna, literature, cinema, and the fine arts. Whoever answers the question correctly can move with his piece as many squares on the pyramid fields as the question card gives. Within the pyramid, you can move in any direction through the corridors, but you must not cross the walls and doors. The doors can only be crossed by answering a door opener card, but it is by no means certain that the door will be open and allow the adventurer to pass. When a player gives a correct answer to a door opener question, the door is revealed and you will know whether that door is open in any direction or if it has been blocked for a long time by a stone collapse. With the Szabadulj kvíz game, everyone can have fun, gain new knowledge, test their knowledge and learn many interesting things!

name: Punchline
description:
Players take turns acting as the "emcee", a moderator position, every round. The emcee randomly draws a card from one of several categories and reads the it aloud. This "cue card" contains an unfinished joke. Each Comedian (player) must devise and write down a completed version of the joke. The players pass their completed jokes to the emcee, who then reads them in a random order. Each player then votes for his/her favorite (beside their own, of course). The player with the most votes gets to keep the cue card. The first player to receive a certain number of cue cards (based on the number of players), wins.

The categories are as follows:

Punchline
The Cue Card gives the punchline to a joke. The Comedian (player) must write the setup (beginning) of the joke.

Missing Pieces
The Cue Card gives a one liner with some pieces missing. The
Comedian must finish writing the one liner by filling each blank
with one or more words.

What's So Funny?
The Cue Card gives the setup to a joke. The Comedian must
write the punchline.

Bright Idea
The Cue Card gives the setup to the ever-popular “light bulb”
joke. The Comedian must write the punchline.

Limerick
The Cue Card gives the first four lines of a limerick. The
Comedian must write the fifth line.

Tie-breaker
In the case that two or more comedians receive an equal number of votes, a tie-breaker round must be played. The emcee draws a card from the top of the tie-breaker photo card pile and shows it to all comedians. Each tying comedian writes a humorous caption for the photo. When all captions have been completed, each competing comedian reads his/her caption aloud. The non-competing players then vote for the funniest caption. The comedian who receives the most votes receives the original cue card.

There are several booster packs.

name: The Snow Queen
description:
The Snow Queen is a card game inspired by the famous fairy tale by Hans Christian Andersen.

Push your luck to win the best friendship cards but be careful not to reach 10 in a colour that will cause you to bust. The question is simple: Take a card or stop? The set of friendship cards on offer changes every round so the challenge is knowing when to take the card and when to stop.

About the fairy tale:
The Snow Queen has frozen Kay's heart. His best friend Gerda embarks on a long journey to save their friendship while there is still time. She travels across mountains, snow covered forests and frozen lakes towards the cold north, before finally lifting the Snow Queen's curse and proving that friendship conquers all.

name: Cranium Sculptorades
description:
The "Can You Sculpt It?" game.

Mold a bowl of that comfort food you crave on a cold day. You might even find yourself sculpting a skateboard or fashioning a flamingo! Will your teammates guess what you are sculpting before time runs out?

Imagine: a whole game dedicated to your favorite classic Cranium activity! With Cranium Favorites, you'll work to get your teammates guessing funny clues as you race against the clock. Stores in a convenient container for a quick dose of fun at home or on the go!

name: Word Grab
description:
The game plays like a Word Rummy variant where players draw tiles and try to complete words from them.

Other players may steal words already formed by other players by crating a new word (a new meaning, adding a plural does not count,) or an anagram with the addition of a new letter.

At the end the score is taken from the value of each letter used.

From the website:

Classic Party Games - Word Grab

Other word games are for wimps

These delightful party games offer great family entertainment with a stylish 1950s feel.

It doesn’t get more retro than this classic party game, with its stylish 1950s feel. A must for nerdy types who love Scrabble.

This is a fast-paced, word-making, word-taking, exciting and challenging game to play. You compete to collect as many words as possible, by either using new letters as they are revealed or by spotting anagrams and poaching your opponents' words!

Contents:


90 letter tiles
full instructions


Players: 2 to 8

http://www.thelagoongroup.com/Details.aspx?subcat=140&;code=7558
categories: Card Game, Party Game, Real-time, Word Game
mechanics: Open Drafting, Pattern Recognition, Set Collection

name: Horton Hears a Who! You to the Rescue!
description:
Horton Hears a Who! - You to the Rescue!
The jump-up-and-go silly search game!

Go on a wild adventure to save the Whos! Put on the Horton hat and race around the house to find the clovers where the tiny Whos live. Pick them up with your trunk—then hurry back before time runs out! The player who rescues the most Whos is the winner!

Horton Hears a Who! – You to the Rescue! brings the classic Dr. Seuss book to life, giving kids a whole new incredibly fun way to experience this favorite Dr. Seuss story.

name: MindMaze: Verzwickte Rätsel – Geld, Ruhm und Macht
description:
In MindMaze: Verzwickte Rätsel - Geld, Ruhm und Macht, as in other MindMaze sets, players take turns asking questions to try to solve mysteries, in this case dark, morbid tales.

In general, a referee tells a strange story, then the players must determine why and how the story happened by asking "Yes" or "No" questions, with "Not Important" also being a plausible answer. Players take turns asking questions, with a point being subtracted for each question. Players are awarded points for asking certain key questions that eliminate faux versions of the story. The list of useful key questions is attached to every riddle. This sort of gaming procedure effectively encourages players to develop careful analytical questions and eliminates random questions.

name: Lexicon-Go
description: Though this is based on the long-established card game of Lexicon, it isn't just a new edition of the same game. The 52 letter cards of the original game are replaced here with 52 letter tiles. These can be used to play the original game but they also introduce a new speed game. This dispenses with the letter values used in the original game and it dispenses with conventional turns. Instead it is played over 5 rounds, with the winner of each round simply being the fastest player to use all 10 of his letter tiles.
